title: The parameter in the POST query allows to control size of returned page which in turn can lead to the potential DOS attack

profile.name: LocalTapiola
profile.about: LocalTapiolaâ€™s products and services cover non-life, life and pension insurance, as well as investment and saving services.

vulnerability_information:
> NOTE! Thanks for submitting a report! Please replace **all** the [square] sections below with the pertinent details. Do not remove any subsections of this template. If the report is not complete, we will most likely close your report with no further action. **QUALITY BEFORE QUANTITY**. Remember, the more detail you provide, the easier it is for us to verify and then potentially issue a bounty, so be sure to take your time filling out the report. Use backticks for codesamples and URL's.

## Basic report information
**Summary:** The parameter in the POST query allows to control size of returned page which in turn can lead to the potential DOS attack

**Description:** I found the parameter in the POST query which allows to control the size of the returned page. Usually this query return the simple JSON error (F249324: 1.png)
If the 'dropdownSize' parameter was changed then we see the same error which is repeated the many times (F249325: 2.png)
This parameter allows to control the size of the returned page. If similar requests will be sent from a large number computers then this can be lead to the potential DOS attack
The POST query is attached (F249327: query.txt)

**Domain:** www.lahitapiola.fi

## Browsers / Apps Verified In:

  * Firefox ESR 45.3.0

## Steps To Reproduce:

(Add details for how we can reproduce the issue)

  1. Change the value in the dropdownSize parameter from the attached query.txt and send the query

## Additional material

  * 1.png
  * 2.png
  * 3.png
  * query.txt

## Related reports, best practices

## Impact

The attacker can make a machine or network resource unavailable

activities.message:
Thanks a lot for reporting this potential issue back to us. LocalTapiola takes security very seriously and would appreciate if you would not share any information about this report until we have determined whether this is a bug and what any potential impact (or fix) will be.

Our security team will take a look at this issue as soon as possible. We aim to respond to your report as soon as possible, but due to the complexity of the systems, triaging many times can take a long time. We prioritize issues -  reports containing trivial issues with limited (or no) business impact and badly written reports with insufficient information on how to reproduce the issue receive a lower priority. Please do not request updates for at least 20 days into the process. Once triaged and verified, bounty decisions are made 1-2 times per month.

*Note: if we frequently dismiss your reports, make sure you have read our policy and stay in scope and that you know how to write good reports - https://support.hackerone.com/hc/en-us/articles/211538803-Step-by-Step-How-to-write-a-good-vulnerability-report*

activities.message: Screenshots do not qualify. Please be diligent in supplying us with easily reproducible step-by-step instructions including all necessary data. We cannot work with screenshots alone.

activities.message:
Hi,
Sorry for the inconvenience. May  be video will help with the further investigation? (F249380: PoC.webm)
I found these POST queries in crawling of the network resource ('Spider' tab in the burpsuite tool). Suitable parameters just picked up 

*Steps To Reproduce:*
1. Take any found POST query (the POST parameters of the query should be the same as in the query.txt file)
2. Change POST parameters according to the query.txt file
3. After that we can control the size of the returned page via 'dropdownSize' parameter

You might be on to something here, but the level of reporting is not something we can really work on.

activities.message:
I hope that this attempt is better than the previous one

Basic report information
====================

**Summary:** The issue is reproduced when I submit feedback form. In this case generates a POST request. The parameters of this query allows to control size of returned page which in turn can lead to the potential DOS attack

**Description:** Some pages of the web resource contain forms which client can fill and submit. For example see to screen1.png. When I fill and submit such form then web application generate the POST request of the following kind: {F249457} If there are some mistakes in filling form then the POST request has the response of the following kind: {F249459} If I change POST data to the following data:
>radioListSize=&modeOfContact=&contactLahiTapiola=&campaignID=test4&lt-etunimi='&lt-email=winter@example.com&lt-puhnro='&radioErrorMessage=test61&agreementForMarketing=1&constraintErrorMessage=test5&radioQuestionList=1&soaperrorMessage=test&agreeTerms=&pagename=LahiTapiola%2fLTContactFormReceiver&restServiceError=<&dropdownList=1&formId=1310380442722&lotteryIDList=1&phoneRadioChecked=test&_dropdownSize=15_&lt-postitoimipaikka=SW1A+1AA&captchaName5=tuolin&captchaImage5=captchaImage5&soapServerErrorMessage=test1&acceptTermsErrorMessage=&captchaImage2=captchaImage2&lt-sukunimi=555-555-0199@example.com&captchaImage1=captchaImage1&captchaImage4=captchaImage4&captchaImage3=captchaImage3&captchaName2=syd%c3%a4men&captchaName1=nuotin&captchaName4=apilan&lt-lahiosoite=555-555-0199@example.com&captchaName3=t%c3%a4hden&lt-status=Toivon+yhteydenottoa+s%c3%a4hk%c3%b6postilla&lt-postinumero=1&dropdownErrorMessage=&lt-viesti=1&errorresponse=123456&targetEmail=test2&errorresponse1=123

then I can control the size of the returned page via 'dropdownSize' parameter. The value of this parameter is equals to number of repetitions of the output error: {F249461}
For example attacker can change the value of 'dropdownSize' parameter to 100000 or more and send this POST request from a large number computers constantly. So this may lead to the denial of service.

**Domain:** www.lahitapiola.fi

Browsers / Apps Verified In:
====================
* Firefox ESR 45.3.0

Steps To Reproduce:
====================
1. Run  the web-developer tool (or any other tool) and begin the tracing of the network activity
2. Go to the any url from link.txt file
3. Fill all fields of the form with text values
4. Choose correct picture and press submit button
5. After that you can see POST request in the web-developer tool (screen2.png)
6. Change the POST data of this request to the following:

>radioListSize=&modeOfContact=&contactLahiTapiola=&campaignID=test4&lt-etunimi='&lt-email=winter@example.com&lt-puhnro='&radioErrorMessage=test61&agreementForMarketing=1&constraintErrorMessage=test5&radioQuestionList=1&soaperrorMessage=test&agreeTerms=&pagename=LahiTapiola%2fLTContactFormReceiver&restServiceError=<&dropdownList=1&formId=1310380442722&lotteryIDList=1&phoneRadioChecked=test&_dropdownSize=15_&lt-postitoimipaikka=SW1A+1AA&captchaName5=tuolin&captchaImage5=captchaImage5&soapServerErrorMessage=test1&acceptTermsErrorMessage=&captchaImage2=captchaImage2&lt-sukunimi=555-555-0199@example.com&captchaImage1=captchaImage1&captchaImage4=captchaImage4&captchaImage3=captchaImage3&captchaName2=syd%c3%a4men&captchaName1=nuotin&captchaName4=apilan&lt-lahiosoite=555-555-0199@example.com&captchaName3=t%c3%a4hden&lt-status=Toivon+yhteydenottoa+s%c3%a4hk%c3%b6postilla&lt-postinumero=1&dropdownErrorMessage=&lt-viesti=1&errorresponse=123456&targetEmail=test2&errorresponse1=123

and send request

**Actual result:** Changing of the value 'dropdownSize' parameter we can control size of the returnted page. (PoC: with_browser.webm)


Additional material
====================
* links.txt - This file contain URLs to the pages which contain forms which generates vulnerable POST requests what I found
* post_requests.txt - This file contain potential malicious POST requests what I found
* bs_part_1.webm and bs_part_2.webm - Those videos contain example how to find all vulnerable POST requests

Related reports, best practices
====================

Impact
====================

For example attacker can change the value of 'dropdownSize' parameter to 100000 or more and send this POST request from a large number computers constantly. So this may lead to the denial of service.

For example attacker can change the value of 'dropdownSize' parameter to 100000 or more and send this POST request from a large number computers constantly. So this may lead to the denial of service.

  6. Change the POST data of this request to the following:

radioListSize=&modeOfContact=&contactLahiTapiola=&campaignID=test4&lt-etunimi='&lt-email=winter@example.com&lt-puhnro='&radioErrorMessage=test61&agreementForMarketing=1&constraintErrorMessage=test5&radioQuestionList=1&soaperrorMessage=test&agreeTerms=&pagename=LahiTapiola%2fLTContactFormReceiver&restServiceError=<&dropdownList=1&formId=1310380442722&lotteryIDList=1&phoneRadioChecked=test&dropdownSize=15&lt-postitoimipaikka=SW1A+1AA&captchaName5=tuolin&captchaImage5=captchaImage5&soapServerErrorMessage=test1&acceptTermsErrorMessage=&captchaImage2=captchaImage2&lt-sukunimi=555-555-0199@example.com&captchaImage1=captchaImage1&captchaImage4=captchaImage4&captchaImage3=captchaImage3&captchaName2=syd%c3%a4men&captchaName1=nuotin&captchaName4=apilan&lt-lahiosoite=555-555-0199@example.com&captchaName3=t%c3%a4hden&lt-status=Toivon+yhteydenottoa+s%c3%a4hk%c3%b6postilla&lt-postinumero=1&dropdownErrorMessage=&lt-viesti=1&errorresponse=123456&targetEmail=test2&errorresponse1=123

and send request

Actual result: Changing of the value 'dropdownSize' parameter we can control size of the returnted page. (PoC: with_browser.webm)

Additional material

  • links.txt - This file contain URLs to the pages which contain forms which generates vulnerable POST requests what I found
  • post_requests.txt - This file contain potential malicious POST requests what I found
  • bs_part_1.webm and bs_part_2.webm - Those videos contain example how to find all vulnerable POST requests

Related reports, best practices

Impact

For example attacker can change the value of 'dropdownSize' parameter to 100000 or more and send this POST request from a large number computers constantly. So this may lead to the denial of service.

summaries.content:
##Issue
The reporter found a parameter which enabled you to generate a potentially huge load on the server by just modifying a parameter value.

##Fix

The application was patched.

##Reasoning

Initially the report was very unprofessional, lacking almost everything needed. Usually reports with this level of information are closed immediately - the quality of the report rarely gets better with iterations, rather they spiral into something even worse. However, the speculation in this report, although not reproducible with the information provided in the initial report, was interesting and raised some eyebrows. With some additional guidance the reporter in the end produced a very nice actionable report - thank you for that. This is a learning opportunity for (waaaaay too) many people submitting reports - if you don't put in the effort, don't expect the results.
summaries.content_html:
Issue

The reporter found a parameter which enabled you to generate a potentially huge load on the server by just modifying a parameter value.

Fix

The application was patched.

Reasoning

Initially the report was very unprofessional, lacking almost everything needed. Usually reports with this level of information are closed immediately - the quality of the report rarely gets better with iterations, rather they spiral into something even worse. However, the speculation in this report, although not reproducible with the information provided in the initial report, was interesting and raised some eyebrows. With some additional guidance the reporter in the end produced a very nice actionable report - thank you for that. This is a learning opportunity for (waaaaay too) many people submitting reports - if you don't put in the effort, don't expect the results.
